Award.AwardTitle: What Controls Selenenic Acids? Understanding the Biochemistry of Selenocysteine

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
TITLE: What Controls Selenenic Acids? Understanding the Biochemistry of Selenocysteine

This project studies the fundamental biochemistry of selenium containing proteins in order to uncover the unique advantages gained from employing selenium instead of sulfur and which ultimately make selenoproteins essential constituents of cellular life. During the course of these scientific efforts an undergraduate student with disabilities will be continuously trained. Starting in the freshmen year, the student will be provided with far-reaching mentoring and training by the research group. In addition, the student will receive support through an extensive network that originated from our accompanying REU program for students facing similar challenges and that is aimed at increasing participation of students with disabilities in the STEM disciplines. Experiences will be widely shared with both STEM students and professionals in order to raise awareness and to ultimately increase opportunities and participation of the disability community in the scientific, social and financial structure of our society. Likewise, society will benefit from increased acceptance of such minorities and subgroups, promoting infusion of their ideas, influences and expertise.

The element selenium, incorporated into the rare amino acid selenocysteine, is used by nature to expand the chemical versatility of enzymes beyond what is available through the 20 canonical amino acids. The resulting selenoproteins are mostly enzymes that are involved in cellular signal transduction, detoxification, and maintenance of oxidants. While it is widely assumed that the use of selenium in proteins must impart unique properties and particular advantages, the key differences that set selenoproteins apart remain to be systematically studied and described. This research will focus on the reaction intermediate, selenenic acid, that is formed when selenocysteine reacts with oxidants. These highly reactive acids can undergo numerous reactions with nearby thiols, amines, amides and oxidants, which will affect selenoproteins interactions with itself and other proteins and ultimately modulate their function in signaling cascades. In order to understand this effect on biological function, 77Se NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry will be used to study the lifetimes of selenenic acid, their tendency to be further oxidized by oxidants and their interactions with protein partners. Together this forms a research plan that is designed to illuminate how selenoproteins control this unusual semi-metallic amino acid, selenocysteine, and harness its chemical properties for cellular use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Significant results

Together with the group of Dr. Fox at the University of Delaware, we developed novel reagents to trap sulfenic (S-OH) and selenenic acids (Se-OH), important short-lived signaling intermediates (Fig 1c), in proteins. The probes are able to map sulfenic and selenenic acid levels and were able to detect a profound difference between the sulfenic acid levels of proteins in cancer and healthy cells. Our reagent is not only selective and allows the trapping of these transient intermediates in live cells but is also quenchable in vivo. This affords spatiotemporal control over the labeling reaction. It also minimizes sample preparation artifacts that take place during cell lysis and downstream processing. Thus, our new probes carry the promise to illuminate changes in cellular signaling that occur, for example, when cells turn cancerous.

In a separate study, we described how the local environment of selenoamino acids in proteins modulates 77Se-NMR properties. To further advance studies of macromolecules by 77Se spectroscopy, we have tackled both bottlenecks. Firstly, we have developed several facile and cost-effective methods for isotopically enriching selenoproteins by 77Se. Secondly, we conducted a variety of 77Se-NMR studies, including work where we systematically introduced selenomethionine at different positions in the same protein to establish how different interactions and local environments influence the NMR spectra of 77Se. By exploiting that the chemical properties of selenomethionine and methionine are almost identical, we have focused on using the amino acid selenomethionine to probe the local structure and conformational mobility in proteins (Fig 1c). We acquired -in collaboration with Dr. Bahnson from the University of Delaware and Mark Allaire from LBL- high-resolution structures of a library of variants of a protein with a single selenomethionine placed at different positions. We then measured the complete information on the chemical shift (i.e., the chemical shift tensor) using solid-state 77Se-NMR. This is the first such record for 77Se in a macromolecule and establishes a framework for the future characterization of selenium sites at proteins. Our experimental design also allowed us to combine the high-resolution structural information on the atoms in 77Se's proximity and the conformational mobility measurements of the different selenomethionine sites. This ultimately enabled a systematic interpretation of the impact of methionine's environment in a protein on the observable Se77Se-NMR parameters. In our latest work, we used distance measurements between 77Se and nearby 13C atoms to map the local environment of a selenium site. Such measurements can now be used to employ selenomethionine as a reporter of protein interfaces, ligand binding, and conformational mobility in proteins. This opens the door to use 77Se-NMR to study how biological systems carry out recognition, binding, and change of conformation and to understand how proteins stabilize seleninic acids. 

Integrative Outreach and Educational Activities:

 Drs. Booksh and Rozovsky have developed a unique summer outreach program, “Research Experience for Undergraduates: Science and Engineering Leadership Initiative,” to encourage undergraduate students with physical and learning disabilities to share in the experience and enjoyment of science. The program specifically caters to undergraduate students with physical, neurobiological, emotional, and learning disabilities and enables them to take part in active research and the enjoyment of Chemistry at a research-intensive University. Furthermore, we put much effort in equipping the participants with the knowledge and skills to successfully pursue a career in chemical professions. The ongoing summer program, currently funded by a renewed NSF award (as well as this grant by providing research opportunities for students with disabilities), has been highlighted by several news outlets such as the ACS Chemical and Engineering News and won awards. We deliberate seek candidates that have no research opportunities in their home institution or whose resume may mark them as too non-traditional for other, conventional REU programs. Yet, our success is palpable as many of our REU participants have moved on to professional and doctoral programs. Our last two cohorts alone (before COVID-19 suspended our program temporarily in 2020) nurtured several exceptional students that went on to receive distingue awards such as the Goldwater Scholar and National Science Foundation's Graduate Research Fellowship. In addition, to advance each participant as an individual, the program has also built its own community and network of former participants that provide support, motivation, and help to many students confronted with similar challenges. In fact, several of our former students have become active advocates, thus producing a multiplier effect through the program that has created and shaped much-needed role models for Chemists with disabilities. With the growing reputation of our program, Drs. Booksh and Rozovsky are often approached by other Universities to help develop similar programs, and we have become informal advisors to many such efforts.
